html:
Tutorial

Here are the steps to update your iPhone

Before you start, your iPhone must be connected to Wi-Fi.

and have at least 50% battery or be plugged in to a power source to download and install updates.

It’s also a good idea to back up your iPhone before installing updates to avoid any potential data loss.

WI-FI

Make sure your iPhone is connected to a Wi-Fi network.

To check if your iPhone is connected to Wi-Fi swipe down from the top right corner of the screen to open the Control Center.

Look for the Wi-Fi icon. If the icon is blue, your iPhone is connected to a Wi-Fi network. If the icon is gray, your iPhone is not connected to a Wi-Fi network.

Alternatively, you can go to Settings and then Wi-Fi to see a list of available Wi-Fi networks. If you are connected to a network, the name of the network will be displayed next to Wi-Fi with a checkmark next to it.

If you are having trouble connecting to Wi-Fi, make sure that the Wi-Fi network is in range and that you have the correct network name and password.

You can also try resetting your network settings by going to Settings > General > Reset > Reset Network Settings.

Battery

Make sure your iPhone has enough battery life or is connected to a power source during the update process.

To check your iPhone’s battery level look at the top right corner of your iPhone’s screen. You should see a battery icon.

The battery icon will show how much battery life you have remaining. A green battery icon indicates that your iPhone’s battery is above 20%, while a red battery icon indicates that your battery is below 20% and needs to be charged soon.

If you want to see the exact percentage of your battery life, swipe down from the top right corner of your iPhone’s screen to open the Control Center. Your battery percentage will be displayed at the top right of the screen.

Note: If your iPhone is running iOS 14 or later, you can also see a breakdown of your battery usage by going to Settings > Battery. This will show you which apps are using the most battery life and provide other helpful battery-related information.

Back up

Make sure to back up your iPhone before updating to ensure you don’t lose any data.

To backup your iPhone, you can use either iCloud or your computer.

Backing up to iCloud connect your iPhone to Wi-Fi.

Go to Settings > [Your Name] > iCloud > iCloud Backup.

Toggle on iCloud Backup if it isn’t already on.

Tap Back Up Now to start the backup process. Keep your iPhone connected to Wi-Fi and power until the backup is complete.

iTunes Backup

Backing up to your computer connect your iPhone to your computer using a USB cable.

Open iTunes on your computer (if you’re using a Mac with macOS Catalina or later, use Finder instead).

Click on the iPhone icon in iTunes or Finder.

Under Backups, choose This computer.Click Back Up Now to start the backup process.

Update Step 1

Now you are ready to update your iphone.

Go to the Settings app on your iPhone and tap on General.

Tap on Software Update.

Your iPhone will check for any available updates. If an update is available, tap on Download and Install.

If your iPhone is low on storage space, you may need to delete some apps or files to make room for update.

You can check your storage space by going to Settings > General >iPhoneStorage.

Update Step 2

If Download and Install prompted, enter your passcode.

Tap Agree to the terms and conditions.

and the size of the update.

Update Step 3

Once the update is downloaded, tap on Install Now.

Your iPhone will restart and begin installing the update. This process may take several minutes.

Once the update is installed, your iPhone will restart again and you will be prompted to enter your passcode.

Update Step 4

After entering your passcode, your iPhone will complete the update and you will be able to use it normally

Check this after your update

After updating your iPhone, there are a few things you can do to make sure the update went well:

Check the software version: Go to Settings > General > Software Update and make sure your iPhone is running the latest version of iOS.

Test basic functions: Test the basic functions of your iPhone such as making a phone call, sending a text message, connecting to Wi-Fi, and accessing the internet to make sure everything is working properly.

Check for any issues: Check for any issues or error messages that might appear after the update. If you notice any issues, try restarting your iPhone or resetting the settings to see if it resolves the issue.

Check battery usage: Check your battery usage to make sure it’s not draining too quickly or experiencing any unusual behavior. You can do this by going to Settings > Battery and checking the usage statistics.

Test new features: If the update includes new features, try them out to see if they work as expected.

If you encounter any issues, try restarting your iPhone or contacting Apple support for further assistance.*

Automatic Updates

Enabling automatic updates means that your iPhone will automatically download and install new updates when they become available, without requiring any action on your part. This can be convenient because it ensures that your iPhone is always up-to-date with the latest security fixes, bug fixes, and new features.

To enable automatic updates on your iPhone go to the Settings app on your iPhone. Tap on General. Tap on Software Update.

Turn on the toggle switch next to Automatic Updates.

Why you should consider enabling automatic updates

There are several reasons why you should consider enabling automatic updates on your iPhone:

Security: New updates often include important security fixes that address vulnerabilities and proteatial threats. Bug Fixes: Updates can also fix bugs and improve the overall stability and performance of your iPhone.

New Features: Updates can add new features and improvements to your iPhone, providing you with an enhanced user experience.

Convenience: Enabling automatic updates can save you time and effort because you don’t have to manually check for updates and install them yourself. Overall, enabling automatic updates can help ensure that vour iPhone is secure, stable, and up-to-date with the latest features and improvements.

Update Battery Issues

If your iPhone doesn’t have enough power during an automatic update, it can cause problems. The update process requires a certain amount of battery life to complete, and if your iPhone runs out of power during the update, it could result in a failed update or even damage to your device.

To prevent this from happening, it’s recommended to keep your iPhone charged before starting an update. Ideally, you should have at least 50% battery life before beginning the update process.

You can also connect your iPhone to a power source during the update to ensure that it doesn’t run out of power.

Low Power Mode

Additionally, you can enable the “Low Power Mode” feature on your iPhone to help conserve battery life during the update. This feature reduces power consumption by disabling certain features, such as automatic downloads, email fetch, and some visual effects.

To enable Low Power Mode, go to Settings > Battery > Low Power Mode.

Overall, it’s important to make sure your iPhone has enough power before starting an automatic update to avoid potential issues.

Issues

If your iPhone doesn’t have enough power during an automatic update, it can cause a few potential issues:

Update failure: The update process may fail or stop midway due to lack of power. This can cause your iPhone to get stuck in a partially updated state, which may require you to restore your iPhone to its previous version.

Data loss: If the update fails, it may cause data loss or corruption. This can include photos, videos, music, and other important data stored on your iPhone.

Battery damage: If your iPhone runs out of power during an update, it can cause damage to the battery. Repeated interruptions during software updates can shorten the lifespan of the battery and cause it to degrade faster over time.

Device instability: If the update process is interrupted, it can cause your iPhone to become unstable or behave erratically. This can include issues like app crashes, freezing, or slow performance.

In order to avoid these problems, it’s important to make sure your iPhone has enough battery life before starting an automatic update.

You should also make sure you have a stable internet connection and enough storage space on your device to complete the update.
